author: By Dina Gachman, Erik Piepenburg, Jason Bailey and Amy Nicholson
title: Thanksgiving Movies for Kids, With All the Trimmings
description: If you’re looking for something to watch with your family after the meal, pick from one of these seasonal selections.
content: From a nostalgic, black-and-white 1947 classic to a romp about animated, time-traveling turkeys, plenty of options abound when it comes to picking a Thanksgiving movie to watch with your kids during the holiday. Our writers picked their favorite Thanksgiving themed movies and specials that are currently streaming. Expect singing mice, dogs in chef’s hats and goth girls burning down a Thanksgiving pageant. The stories span the last 76 years, but as the decades roll by, each one still feels timeless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Supreme Court’s Search for a More Attractive Gun Rights Case
description: The next big Second Amendment case, after one on domestic violence, could be about whether the government can disarm a man who lied to get food stamps.
content: When the Supreme Court heard arguments this month on whether the Second Amendment allows the government to disarm domestic abusers, Justice Amy Coney Barrett made a cryptic reference that puzzled many in the courtroom. She asked, according to the court’s official transcript, about “the range issue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Thanksgiving Puzzle Answers 2023
description: See the answers for “Two Truths and a Pie” and our dessert-themed crossword
content: If you haven’t played the puzzles yet, you can find them here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: My Head Is Always Cold. Can I Wear Hats Indoors?
description: To help a reader navigate the fuzzy etiquette of covering up indoors, our critic weighs the merits of beanies, fedoras and ear-warmers.
content: To wear or not to wear a hat indoors was once a very simple question. For men, a fedora or trilby was an outdoor accessory for commuting between home and office. Once inside, they removed it immediately. For women, a hat worn as part of an outfit was allowed to stay on the head pretty much always, in part out of sensitivity to the hat-head hairdo problem; in part out of recognition that a hat is part of a look, like a necklace or shoes; and in part because, well, you try putting on a fascinator and taking it off at will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Mysterious Respiratory Illness Affects Dogs in Multiple States
description: The illness can include a cough, fever, lethargy and a loss of appetite. Veterinarians recommend that owners avoid boarding their dog if it shows symptoms.
content: Laboratories in at least four states are investigating a mysterious respiratory illness in dogs that are presenting similar symptoms to kennel cough, but it can last much longer, and in some cases prove fatal, according to veterinarians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Federal Court Moves to Drastically Weaken Voting Rights Act
description: The ruling, which is almost certain to be appealed to the Supreme Court, would effectively bar private citizens and civil rights groups from suing under a key provision of the landmark law.
content: A federal appeals court moved on Monday to drastically weaken the Voting Rights Act, issuing a ruling that would effectively bar private citizens and civil rights groups from filing lawsuits under a central provision of the landmark civil rights law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: Thanksgiving Specials and Holiday Movies
description: The Macy’s Day Parade, an annual dog show and a Friends marathon air on Thanksgiving. And Christmas movies are here, including “Love Actually” and “The Holiday.”
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 20-Nov. 26. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Francesca Paris
title: The Great Disconnect: Why Voters Feel One Way About the Economy but Act Differently
description: Americans are angry and anxious, and not just about prices, which may be driving economic sentiment more than their financial situations, economists said.
content: By traditional measures, the economy is strong. Inflation has slowed significantly. Wages are increasing. Unemployment is near a half-century low. Job satisfaction is up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Collier
title: ‘A Horror Film’: Mothers in Gaza on Giving Birth in a War Zone
description: The U.N. says that an estimated 50,000 pregnant women are caught up in the conflict in Gaza. Palestinian officials warn that the health care system has collapsed.
content: “My experience during childbirth was a nightmare in every sense of the word, or something like a horror film,” said 29-year-old Wajiha al-Abyad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: An Ex-Detective’s Overturned Murder Cases Have Cost New York $110 Million
description: Louis N. Scarcella, a former N.Y.P.D. detective, was accused of framing dozens of people for murder. The city and state have paid a steep price to settle claims over the past decade.
content: A single New York City police detective accused of trying to close murder cases by concocting false witness testimony and coercing confessions has cost taxpayers $110 million in settlements to more than a dozen people whose convictions were overturned after some had spent decades in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: The Science Behind the Dreaded Red Wine Headache
description: Is it sulfites, tannins or another culprit? Here’s what the research says about the migraines some people get with a glass of merlot.
content: People have been complaining about wine headaches since ancient Greece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Deadly Strike Rocks a Hospital in Gaza, Where Few Are Still Working
description: The strike killed 12 people, officials said, at the Indonesian Hospital in the Gaza Strip, where the U.N. says most hospitals no longer function and those that do cannot provide complex care.
content: Another hospital in the Gaza Strip came under fire on Monday, as the World Health Organization warned that the enclave’s devastated health system had largely collapsed, with none of its functioning hospitals capable of handling complicated medical cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger and Maggie Shannon
title: Las Vegas Grand Prix: ‘It Was a Lot of a Lot’
description: Ben Affleck, Jennifer Lopez, Jimmy Kimmel and more converged on the city for a Formula 1 race held over the weekend.
content: “If this was an R-rated comedy, and they put all these set pieces together like the poker, and the cars, and the Vegas of it all, no one would buy this movie,” said Hamish Linklater, an actor and playwright.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Dinners That Don’t Feel Insane to Cook the Week of Thanksgiving
description: You’ve got a feast to prep. We’ve got 15-minute garlic noodles, tomato rice with crispy Cheddar and sheet-pan bibimbap.
content: With all the pre-Thanksgiving preparations going on — the list-checking and turkey brining, the stock-simmering and pie-crust rolling — making actual dinners this week can feel like too much. A legit move is to order in, of course. But here’s another thought: Why wait for takeout when we at New York Times Cooking have a veritable cornucopia of excellent alternatives that are nearly as easy, just as fast (if not faster) and certainly more economical?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Tripp Mickle and Mike Isaac
title: OpenAI Staff Threatens Exodus, Jeopardizing Company’s Future
description: A board member who was part of Sam Altman’s ouster as chief executive joined a majority of the company’s staff in calling for the decision’s reversal.
content: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Garrett Schumann
title: Her Music Fell Into Obscurity. Now It’s Back at the Philharmonic.
description: Julia Perry’s “Stabat Mater” was well received in the 1950s. But it took until this week for the New York Philharmonic to program it.
content: The New York Philharmonic’s program this week contains familiar names, Gustav Holst and György Ligeti. But in between is a first for the orchestra: “Stabat Mater,” a 1951 work for contralto and strings by Julia Perry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Families of Hostages in Gaza Are Desperate for Proof of Life
description: Hamas has offered no information about the nearly 240 hostages, including children, who are said to be held in Gaza.
content: Forty-four days after Hersh Goldberg-Polin, 23, was seized by Hamas, his left arm blown off by a hand grenade, his parents have no idea if he is dead or alive, hidden somewhere in the rubble of Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhoda Feng
title: ‘United States v. Gupta’ Review: Father’s Trial, Daughter’s Song
description: Deepali Gupta offers a meandering and muddled take on the trial of Rajat Gupta, a former head of McKinsey & Company.
content: “The problem with exposition is, why would you want a map when you’re trying to get lost?” asks Deepali Gupta near the start of “United States v. Gupta.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Shakira Reaches Deal in Spanish Tax Fraud Case
description: Prosecutors had charged the pop star with failing to pay 14.5 million euros in income taxes. Her trial had been set to begin on Monday.
content: The international pop star Shakira reached a deal with Spanish prosecutors to settle a multimillion-euro tax evasion case on Monday, just before the trial was set to begin in Barcelona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: The latest from the war in Gaza.
content: On the fifth day of its operation inside the Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City, the Israeli military released video of what it said was a 55-meter (180-foot) section of a fortified tunnel running 10 meters beneath the complex, seeking to bolster its allegations that Hamas has used it as a base for its military operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: What Is COP28? And Other Questions About the Big U.N. Climate Summit
description: Diplomats and leaders will gather in Dubai for United Nations climate talks. Here are some key facts.
content: Two facts loom over United Nations climate talks that begin Nov. 30 in Dubai: the planet is careening toward climate disaster, and governments are acting too slowly to avert the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Lise Davidsen Is an Opera Star Worth Traveling For
description: Her high notes emerging like shafts of sunlight, Davidsen is playing the title role in Janacek’s “Jenufa” at the struggling Lyric Opera of Chicago.
content: A new pop song is the same streamed anywhere. And if you wanted to see Beyoncé this year, she likely came to a town not far from you, giving pretty much the same show in Barcelona as she did in Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: OpenAI’s Future in Doubt
description: Plus India’s cricket heartbreak.
content: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter yesterday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Biden vs. Trump the ‘Election We Need’?
description: Readers react to a column by Carlos Lozada that argues that it is. Also: Rosalynn Carter’s life; protests at Columbia University; Bidenomics.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Earl Thomas
title: To These Writers, Video Games Are Not Just Entertainment, but Art
description: In the anthology “Critical Hits,” gamers like Hanif Abdurraqib, Alexander Chee and Larissa Pham explain what the medium means to them.
content: At their best, video games can offer a path through difficulty, in both reality and fiction. In Ka Vang’s short story “Ms. Pac-Man Ruined My Gang Life,” a Hmong teenager escapes domestic trouble in an arcade; in Jamil Jan Kochai’s “Playing Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain,” an Afghan American boy grows “oddly immune” to the dissonance of shooting video-game targets who resemble his father; in Raven Leilani’s novel “Luster,” Edie and Akila break bread in Overcooked after the police attempt to break their spirits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu and Tripp Mickle
title: Cruise’s C.E.O. Quits as the Driverless Carmaker Aims to Rebuild Trust
description: Kyle Vogt, a founder of Cruise, resigned from the company on Sunday, weeks after it suspended all of its self-driving operations.
content: Kyle Vogt, a founder and chief executive of Cruise, the driverless car subsidiary of General Motors, resigned on Sunday, less than a month after Cruise suspended all autonomous operations after a series of traffic mishaps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Alter
title: The Formidable Rosalynn Carter
description: The senior staff in the Carter White House often wished the stubborn president would listen even more to his impressive wife, especially on politics.
content: I saw Rosalynn Carter angry only twice. Both occasions involved Ronald Reagan, who had crushed Jimmy Carter in the 1980 election, and both reflected her passion and decency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Epic Games C.E.O. Says Google Has ‘De Facto Control’ on Android App
description: Tim Sweeney, who runs the company that created Fortnite, testified in a case that, if he wins, could allow competing payment systems on the Play Store.
content: It was a long-awaited day in court for Epic Games’ chief executive, Tim Sweeney, who testified in a San Francisco federal courthouse on Monday in the company’s legal battle against Google.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Hundreds Sentenced in Trial That Sought to Break Mafia’s Grip on Southern Italy
description: The outcome on Monday marked a blow to the criminal syndicate ‘Ndrangheta and some of its top-ranking mobsters with ties to international drug syndicates.
content: Hundreds of defendants were sentenced to prison on Monday in a case that prosecutors and experts said dealt a crucial blow to the Mafia in southern Italy and showed how the mob retains deep ties to cocaine trafficking, but also exerts control over the local economy and institutions through powerful politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 20, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 20, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Why Cold Symptoms Are Worse at Night
description: We asked experts why we cough and sniffle more when we head to bed, and what to do for better sleep.
content: It’s cold and flu season. That means you’re very likely surrounded by a symphony of coughs and sniffling noses — if you’re not actively coughing yourself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What an El Niño Winter Could Mean for California
description: This year’s El Niño weather pattern in the Pacific is expected to be exceptionally strong.
content: Odds are that this winter’s going to be a wet one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The Crisis in Issue Polling, and What We’re Doing About It
description: A poll can be very close to the actual result but miss the key story line. We’ll try new question forms; we might even try an experiment or two.
content: By the usual measures, last year’s midterm polls were among the most accurate on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: What to Know About Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial
description: The short Thanksgiving week will see the parade of expert witnesses continue as the defense argues that the valuations of assets were within normal boundaries.
content: Donald J. Trump’s defense lawyers this week will offer a look into his business operations and continue the parade of expert witnesses testifying on his behalf in a Manhattan courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Keeping the Peace With Road Trip Games
description: The subtle art of staying on speaking terms with your passengers until you reach your destination.
content: So long as travel continues to rebound from the pandemic, American roadways could see well over the 55 million travelers that AAA predicted for last year’s Thanksgiving holiday. And for those opting to join the hordes, these numbers may translate to spending several hours in a car with family members. That way madness lies — and the best of us might lose our wits, but for the grace of car games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Between Israelis and Palestinians, a Lethal Psychological Chasm Grows
description: In a conflict marked by complete incomprehension on both sides, the ability to see each other as human has been lost.
content: Eight years after the foundation of the state of Israel, Moshe Dayan, the chief of staff of the Israeli military, stood close to the Gaza border to pronounce a eulogy for a 21-year-old Israeli security officer slain by Palestinian and Egyptian assailants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Awad
title: Many West Bank Palestinians Are Being Forced Out of Their Villages. Is My Family Next?
description: Settler violence is forcing many Palestinians in the West Bank to flee.
content: I was born in February 1998 in Tuba, a rural shepherding community of 80 Palestinian residents in the South Hebron Hills of the West Bank, where my family has lived for generations. Over the years we have suffered repeated attacks by Israeli settlers, part of an ongoing campaign to remove us from our land. Still, nothing prepared me for what our life has become since the Hamas attack on Oct. 7. In the last six weeks, the raids and harassment by settlers have become so intense that I do not know how much longer I and the other members of my community will be able to live here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Danielle Brooks and Sam Jay on Confidence and ‘The Color Purple’
description: Two creative people in two different fields in one wide-ranging conversation. This time: the actress and the comedian.
content: Viewers first saw the actress Danielle Brooks as Taystee, the smartest and funniest of the prisoners on “Orange Is the New Black,” the incarceration dramedy that began in 2013 and ran for seven seasons on Netflix. This month, she’ll appear in “The Color Purple,” the second film adaptation of Alice Walker’s 1982 novel, this one based on the 2005 Broadway musical it inspired. Brooks’s character, Sofia, forced to work a grueling job as a maid for a white political family in early 1900s Georgia, was portrayed by Oprah Winfrey in Steven Spielberg’s 1985 adaptation; Brooks, 34, a Juilliard School-trained actress who was raised in South Carolina, played her in the musical’s 2015 revival. That production was Brooks’s Broadway debut; last year, she starred alongside Samuel L. Jackson in a revival of August Wilson’s “The Piano Lesson” (1990).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: How Do You Feel When You’re Interrupted?
description: And what strategies, if any, do you use to make sure you’re heard?
content: If you had to sum up in one word what it feels like to be interrupted, what would it be? Why would you describe the experience that way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Kansas School Demands Native American Student Cut His Hair to Attend
description: An 8-year-old boy who is a member of Wyandotte Nation was told by his school that the long hair reflecting his cultural heritage violated its dress code, the A.C.L.U. says.
content: An 8-year-old Native American boy who had grown out his hair to honor his ancestry was made to get a haircut after being threatened with suspension from school, the American Civil Liberties Union of Kansas said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Rosalynn Carter Lauded for Humanitarian Work, Mental Health Advocacy
description: Politicians from both sides of the aisle and other notable figures paid tribute to the former first lady, who died on Sunday.
content: Not long after Rosalynn Carter, the former first lady, died on Sunday, politicians from both sides of the aisle commended her work in that public role and the strides she made for women’s rights, mental health and many other causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Guggenheim Selects Director, First Woman to Lead the Museum Group
description: Mariët Westermann, vice chancellor of N.Y.U.’s Abu Dhabi campus, will come to New York to run the museum complex as it prepares to open Guggenheim Abu Dhabi.
content: As cultural institutions all over the country struggle to make a case for themselves in a digital world, and job descriptions for arts leaders have grown increasingly complex, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation on Monday announced that it had named Mariët Westermann director and chief executive of its museum group. Westermann, the vice chancellor of N.Y.U. Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, will be the first woman to direct the entire museum group, overseeing the Foundation and its flagship institution in New York, as well as its global outposts in Venice, Bilbao, Spain,  and the future Guggenheim Abu Dhabi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘Hell’s Kitchen’ Review: How Alicia Keys Got Her Groove
description: A promising Off Broadway jukebox musical features hits by the R&B star (including “Fallin’,” “If I Ain’t Got You” and “No One”) and a story much like her own.
content: Even in the Golden Age of musical theater, shows so commonly died after intermission that critics came up with a name for the disease. “Second act trouble” presented in many ways: unmoored songs, desperate cutting, illogical crises, hasty workarounds. Yet all those second act symptoms arose from the same underlying condition: first act ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix and Scott Heller
title: My First Trip to ‘Rubyfruit Jungle’
description: Kristen Arnett, k.d. lang, Myriam Gurba and 10 more on Rita Mae Brown’s breakthrough novel about lesbian identity, published 50 years ago this fall.
content: Molly Bolt may not be as renowned as Holden Caulfield, but to those who know her name, she is as much (if not more) of a literary hero. The precocious and fearless protagonist of Rita Mae Brown’s 1973 novel “Rubyfruit Jungle” has served as a model of possibility for generations of young women, lesbians and outsiders of all kinds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: What Republicans Are Missing on Abortion Politics, According to a Republican
description: The G.O.P. is struggling politically with abortion. Jane Coaston interviews South Carolina’s Sandy Senn, who says it is “best to put it to the voters.”
content: Republicans have struggled politically with the issue of abortion since the overturning of Roe v. Wade — a point proven several times over with anti-abortion measures failing in relatively conservative states. Just this month, Ohio added abortion rights to the State Constitution and Republicans lost control of the Virginia Statehouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris, Jan Ransom and José A. Alvarado Jr
title: Behind 94 Acts of Shocking Violence, Years of Glaring Mistakes
description: New York officials have escaped scrutiny for repeated failures to help homeless mentally ill people, a New York Times investigation has found.
content: The last breakdown of Marcus Gomez began in full view of the people whose job it was to stop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A Gaudí-inspired retreat with a guesthouse in Santa Barbara, a 1926 Tudor Revival home in Los Angeles and a renovated midcentury house in San Francisco.
content: This whimsical home, known as the Whale House, was designed by Michael Carmichael, an architect who was inspired by the works of the celebrated Catalan designer Antoni Gaudí to create a layout following the shape of a whale: The entry sits behind an arched opening shaped like a fish mouth; the interior courtyard forms the belly of the whale; and a guest suite resides in the tail. The house has no right angles, and the built-in cabinets, countertops and furniture are tailored to fit into the curved rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By CC Allen
title: Six Hours to Cook and $100 to Shop: Watch 3 NYT Food Writers Make Thanksgiving
description: Spoiler: It’s down to the wire.
content: Thanksgiving can be an expensive holiday, so we wanted to see what three of our colleagues would make with an allowance of $100. We followed Priya Krishna, Vaughn Vreeland and Eric Kim around New York as they shopped for ingredients and made Thanksgiving dinner for their friends. With one hour to shop and six hours to prepare their menus, these cooks raced to see what they could get done within their budgets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Army Ammunition Factory Tied to Mass Shootings Faces New Scrutiny
description: Lawmakers want to know if taxpayers are subsidizing rounds used in AR-15-style guns that are “contributing to serious violence by private citizens.”
content: An agreement between the Army and one of the nation’s largest ammunition manufacturers is receiving new scrutiny because of a little-known provision allowing a government facility to produce hundreds of millions of rounds for the retail market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: How to Watch the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: Stepping off a half-hour earlier than usual, this year’s parade will include 31 floats, 25 balloons and performances by Jon Batiste and Cher.
content: The 97th annual Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade will take place on Thursday, with over three million spectators expected to brave the early-morning cold for a view of the procession’s many floats, balloons and celebrity performers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Helmets Off, Mics Up: N.F.L. Players Discover the Power of Podcasts
description: The N.F.L. tends to suppress individuality, but podcasts from stars like the Kelce brothers, Micah Parsons and Tyreek Hill are popping up as valuable portals to fans.
content: Hours after winning a playoff game with the Kansas City Chiefs in 2020, tight end Travis Kelce chatted with his older brother, Philadelphia Eagles center Jason Kelce, about the intricacies of blocking defensive linemen while the siblings devoured dinner at a steakhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Marx
title: Clothes that Conjure the Holiday Spirit
description: Keith Nielsen, who oversaw costumes for four Hallmark Christmas movies out this year, shares his approach to dressing festively. (It does not involve ugly sweaters.)
content: Several years ago, Keith Nielsen was feeling less than cheerful when a friend told him about an internship opportunity with the costume department of the TV series “Mozart in the Jungle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Radcliffe Bailey, Artist Who Explored Black Migration, Dies at 54
description: His work blended family photographs with symbols of the African diaspora. The story he told, his gallerist said, is “not a ‘me’ thing, it’s a ‘we’ thing.”
content: Radcliffe Bailey, a Georgia-based artist whose collage paintings and sculptural assemblages incorporated family tintypes, African figurines, disassembled piano keys and other objects in an exploration of both his personal history and the broader sorrows and joys of the Black experience, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Atlanta. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Kaiser-Schatzlein
title: Pay Thousands to Quit Your Job? Some Employers Say So.
description: Some U.S. businesses are forcing workers to sign contracts that demand steep “reimbursements” if they leave.
content: Benzor Shem Vidal started caring for his nonverbal autistic brother when he was 12. Vidal’s parents, who lived with the two boys in a small house in steamy Cebu City in the Philippines, didn’t have the money to send his brother to special-education classes, so when Vidal came home from school each day, he would find his brother mumbling to himself in the living room. Vidal would prepare him some food, making sure that he drank water between bites so he wouldn’t choke. Vidal went to nursing school and graduated second in his class, perhaps because he already had a decade of informal experience. When his mother died in 2020, Vidal’s father became his brother’s sole caretaker, leaving Vidal to be the wage-earner for the family. He needed to make more money. So last year, at 26, Vidal moved to America to work at a nursing home in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Happens When a Founder Leaves?
description: The OpenAI drama is an extreme case of an old concern in business.
content: People are going to be talking about the blowup at OpenAI for years. ChatGPT itself — a product of OpenAI — could not have concocted a tale as wild as the one that unfolded over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: A Major Economic Challenge
description: India has one of the world’s lowest rates of formal employment for women.
content: There is one change, so simple it can be described in just six words, that could lift millions of people out of poverty and expand the world’s fifth-largest economy: Get more Indian women paid jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: You Know About the Birds and the Bees, but Guess What These Bats Do
description: Bats have long been known for unusual forms of sexual reproduction, and a new study adds another surprise to the behaviors of the winged mammals.
content: A few years ago, Nicolas Fasel, a biologist at the University of Lausanne in Switzerland, and his colleagues developed a fascination with the penises of serotine bats, a species found in woodlands and the attics of old buildings across Europe and Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: How to Clean Up After Thanksgiving Dinner Like a Pro
description: Getting a handle on the cleaning that comes with cooking is about more than just dishwashing.
content: Dishwashing, the B-side to Thanksgiving cooking, can be as satisfying as preparing the feast. There’s a certainty to the outcome, a calm that comes with cleanliness and a definitive end to all the work for the holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: The Best True Crime to Stream: Family Matters
description: Four picks from television, films and podcasts that show blood is not always thicker than water.
content: Family secrets, tumult and trauma are at the heart of so many — if not most — true crime stories, and breed some of the most bizarre betrayals. Here are four picks including podcasts, television and films that explore unforgettable crimes involving families, all of whom prided themselves on presenting a perfect image until the truth came crashing through the facade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: quackery
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word quackery has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 15 in the book review “A Reason to Cheer for Cells and the Viruses That Feed on Them” by Alex Johnson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: On the Luby’s Cafeteria Line, Every Day Is Thanksgiving
description: The Texas chain, which serves turkey dinners year-round, has come to define the holiday for its loyal customers — and not just with its food.
content: In a spacious Houston cafeteria awash in primary colors, diners crowded around big tables and dug into mashed potatoes splashed with a slick gravy, glossy green beans and sticky slabs of pecan pie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller, Bastian Achard and Christopher Garis
title: On Patmos, in Greece, a Very Old House Gets a Colorful New Life
description: Two designers returned a historic dwelling to its roots, removing everything contemporary — then adding an internationally inflected spirit of their own.
content: THEY CALL IT the Island of the Apocalypse, for it was here on Patmos, in the southeastern corner of what’s today Greece, that John the Apostle foretold the end of the world — or at least the version recorded in the Bible’s Book of Revelation. John had been exiled in A.D. 95 to this speck of land not far from where the Aegean meets the Mediterranean by the Romans, who weren’t only threatened by the rising influence of Christianity but believed it to be a cult. The Byzantine Empire nonetheless took hold, and with it Greek Orthodoxy — and then, in 1088, rose the monastery dedicated to St. John, a fortified structure of marble and native andesite (a volcanic rock), built on one of the highest points on Patmos, that would forever change the island’s fortunes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Stray Kids Score Another No. 1 With ‘Rock-Star’
description: The K-pop group’s mini album opens atop the Billboard 200, bumping Taylor Swift’s remake of “1989” to second place.
content: Stray Kids, the eight-piece K-pop group that was formed on a South Korean reality TV show, has scored its fourth No. 1 in two years on Billboard’s album chart, bumping Taylor Swift to No. 2 after two blockbuster weeks at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Microsoft Hires OpenAI’s Ousted C.E.O., and More
description: Plus, Argentina elects a far-right president and Rosalynn Carter dies at 96.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Rosalynn Carter Helped Shape the Role of the Modern First Lady
description: Mrs. Carter transformed the unelected, unpaid and sometimes unappreciated position of first lady in ways that reverberate to this day.
content: Some two decades after leaving the White House, Rosalynn Carter reflected on the criticism she generated for expanding the role of a first lady. “You can’t let it stop you,” she told an interviewer. “I didn’t let it stop me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: She Once Won Eurovision. Now She’s on Russia’s Wanted List.
description: Jamala, the song contest’s 2016 champion, had been a prominent advocate for Crimea’s Tatar population. The region was annexed from Ukraine by Russia in 2014.
content: Russia has added a popular Ukrainian singer who won the Eurovision song contest seven years ago to its wanted list, as Moscow expands its efforts to target cultural figures who have been critical of its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: This Taxi Has Been Driven 550,000 Miles. Its Days May Be Numbered.
description: There are still two Ford Crown Victorias on the road. “I love this car,” one of the cabdrivers says.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll go for a ride in the two oldest taxis still on the streets of New York City. They are 12 years old. We’ll also find out why the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan says that control over the Rikers Island jails should be taken away from the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: The Carters’ Hometown Mourns for the Love of a Lifetime
description: Their marriage was admired for its endurance — 77 years — and for the affection between the two people in it. “It radiated,” one acquaintance said.
content: There was a time, Rosalynn Carter once confessed, when she dreaded going back to Plains, her tiny Georgia hometown. Actually, she was furious about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The A.I. Industry Was Upended
description: Also, a court moved to weaken the Voting Rights Act. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: The future of OpenAI, the start-up that quickly became a titan of the artificial intelligence industry after its release of ChatGPT last year, is in doubt. The company’s board fired its high-profile chief executive, Sam Altman, on Friday, and in response, more than 700 of the company’s 770 employees signed a letter today threatening to resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cass R. Sunstein
title: Why I Am a Liberal
description: Perhaps more than ever, there is an urgent need for a clear understanding of liberalism.
content: More than at any other time since World War II, liberalism is under siege. On the left, some people insist that liberalism is exhausted and dying and unable to handle the problems posed by entrenched inequalities, corporate power and environmental degradation. On the right, some people think that liberalism is responsible for the collapse of traditional values, rampant criminality, disrespect for authority and widespread immorality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Ouyang
title: The Big #MeToo Moment for Doctors Is Finally Here
description: Why did it take so long?
content: In January of 2016, Aja Newman went to the emergency room at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City for discomfort in her right shoulder. What should’ve been a routine visit instead unfolded as a harrowing, grotesque distortion of the doctor-patient interaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Michael Gold
title: Trump’s Dire Words Raise New Fears About His Authoritarian Bent
description: The former president is focusing his most vicious attacks on domestic political opponents, setting off fresh worries among autocracy experts.
content: Donald J. Trump rose to power with political campaigns that largely attacked external targets, including immigration from predominantly Muslim countries and from south of the United States-Mexico border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Mark Kurlansky Peels Back History’s Layers in ‘The Core of an Onion’
description: Wine organized by texture at Community Wine & Spirits, a talk at 92NY with the chef Massimo Bottura and Lara Gilmore, and more food news.
content: “The Core of an Onion,” Mark Kurlansky’s latest single-subject food book, made me think of Thanksgiving. He devotes an entire chapter to creamed onions, essential at Thanksgiving dinner when I was growing up. His book has recipes for them dated to 1665 and a reference to the 1941 film “They Died With Their Boots On,” in which the onions play a role alongside Errol Flynn. Other discussions of onion cookery — as in soup, stuffed, fried, breads, pickled, with eggs, in sandwiches (famously by James Beard) and more, with recipe histories — follow an unraveling of the onion botanically, historically, medicinally, literally, economically and gastronomically around the world. Despite relevant but overlong digressions on the origins of the Gibson and of the bagel, it’s a lively read. On the culinary side he might have touched on the Spanish tortilla when discussing eggs and onions; he makes an interesting point about swapping cream for milk when using older recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Nations Are Getting Serious About Climate Action. Just Not Serious Enough, U.N. Says.
description: There’s a lot more work to do to keep global temperatures at relatively safe levels, according to a U.N. report issued in advance of global climate talks.
content: The world’s nations are taking more concrete steps to tackle climate change than ever before, but they are still very far from making the sweeping changes needed to keep global temperatures at relatively safe levels, according to a United Nations report issued on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: Turn Your Thanksgiving Leftovers Into a Hot Pocket
description: Somewhere between a calzone and one of those Costco chicken bakes, this recipe from J. Kenji López-Alt makes the most of the feast.
content: It turns out that, if it tastes good together on your Thanksgiving plate, it’ll taste good baked into a pocket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Why We’re Still Breathing Dirty Indoor Air
description: The pandemic and recent wildfires have shown how unhealthy indoor air can be. But scientific and governmental inertia have slowed the necessary remedies.
content: In early 2020, the world scrubbed down surfaces, washed hands and sneezed into elbows, desperate to avoid infection with a new coronavirus. But the threat was not really lying on countertops and doorknobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Why on Earth Are Jewish Leaders Praising Elon Musk?
description: Elon Musk has learned that ardent Zionism can be an alibi for antisemitism.
content: Last week a self-described Jewish conservative named Charles Weber took to X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, to address the “cowards hiding behind the anonymity of the internet and posting ‘Hitler was right.’” Weber dared those trolls to “say it to our faces.” One X user took him up on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Microsoft’s Stock Hits Record High After Hiring OpenAI Outcasts
description: The tech giant moved quickly to hire Sam Altman and others after their abrupt departures from OpenAI, a key Microsoft partner.
content: Microsoft, the technology giant that ranks as one of the world’s most valuable companies, was shaken by the upheaval at OpenAI, the small but influential artificial intelligence start-up that developed the ChatGPT chatbot, before it found a way out of the turmoil that propelled its shares to a new high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Black Friday Travel Sales Are Here and Deals Abound
description: Bargain shoppers will find discounts on hotels, resorts, far-flung tours and cruises. The key is to act quickly before they disappear.
content: As inflation continues to sting, more travelers are expected to hunt for bargains this year, and the industry is responding by offering deals across the travel landscape, from hotels to cruises and tours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: This Is Why Google Paid Billions for Apple to Change a Single Setting
description: Default settings on devices allow the tech industry to keep collecting and using data as it wants.
content: A report in The Guardian in August that lawyers who had had business before the Supreme Court gave money to an aide to Justice Clarence Thomas for a Christmas party was surprising. Just as surprising was the way the publication learned about it: from the aide’s public Venmo records. Brian X. Chen, the consumer technology writer for The Times, wrote that even he was surprised that such records of money transfers could be public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Olivia Natt, Rob Szypko, Mooj Zadie, Rachel Quester, Diane Wong, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The New Speaker Avoided a Shutdown. Can He Avoid Being Ousted?
description: Amid Republican infighting, Mike Johnson relied on Democrats for the bulk of the votes to pass a House spending bill.
content: By working with Democrats to avert a government shutdown this past week, Speaker Mike Johnson seemed to put himself on the same path that doomed his predecessor. Or did he?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Napoleon’s Hat Sells for $2.1 Million at Auction in France
description: The black bicorn hat, believed to have belonged to the 19th-century French emperor, had been expected to sell for far less.
content: A black felt bicorn hat belonging to Napoleon Bonaparte sold for 1.9 million euros, or $2.1 million, at an auction in Fontainebleau, France, on Sunday, fetching the highest price ever paid for one of the 19th-century French emperor’s hats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Stamped From the Beginning’ Review: Examining Racist Thought
description: The documentary, based on Ibram X. Kendi’s 2016 book, looks at the ugly history of anti-Black ideology.
content: The documentary “Stamped From the Beginning,” based on the 2016 book by Ibram X. Kendi, begins with a trick question and ends with a sage retort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: What We Know About the Hostage Negotiations Between Israel and Hamas
description: As Israel and Hamas negotiate over the release of some 240 hostages taken in the armed group’s Oct. 7 attacks, the outlines of a possible deal are taking shape.
content: As Israel and Hamas engage in indirect negotiations over the release of some 240 hostages taken in the armed group’s attacks on Oct. 7, the outlines of a possible deal are taking shape, officials say, although stumbling blocks remain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Court Signals It Could Keep but Narrow Trump Election Case Gag Order
description: A federal appeals court panel is weighing how to balance the former president’s free-speech rights against insulating prosecutors, court personnel and potential witnesses from intimidation.
content: A federal appeals court in Washington appeared to signal at a hearing on Monday that it would keep in place at least some version of the gag order placed on former President Donald J. Trump in the criminal case accusing him of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: At University of Arkansas, a State Law Stifles Pro-Palestinian Speakers
description: To receive a modest speaker’s fee, academics and writers must sign a pledge that they will not participate in anti-Israel boycotts. The author Nathan Thrall said no thank you.
content: A few weeks ago, Nathan Thrall, a Jewish American writer whose work strongly supports Palestinian rights, was invited to speak to students at the University of Arkansas about a new book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Shake-up at OpenAI Reshapes the Industry’s Global Order
description: Big Tech is reeling from the ouster of Sam Altman at a leading A.I. start-up and his subsequent jump to Microsoft, moves that reset the power dynamic underpinning the sector.
content: Over just three days, the landscape for artificial intelligence has been reshaped drastically. On Friday morning, Sam Altman was the C.E.O. of OpenAI, the leader in commercializing generative A.I. through ChatGPT. By Monday, he had not only been fired by his board — he had also joined Microsoft, the start-up’s biggest backer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘No Need to Worry,’ Says ‘Wallace and Gromit’ Film Studio, After Clay Supplier Shuts Down
description: Rumors that Aardman Animations, the makers of stop-motion films, had lost their supplier worried fans. But fear not, the studio reassured, there is plenty of clay.
content: It might have been an existential question for the creators of the beloved stop-motion animation characters Wallace and Gromit and Shaun the Sheep: What would happen if they ran out of clay?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Herbert Gold, Postwar Novelist of Love and Marriage, Dies at 99
description: He emerged in the 1950s as a promising young writer exploring the emotional lives of ordinary men and women and the complexities of Jewish identity in America.
content: Herbert Gold, a novelist whose verbal inventiveness and keen eye for the complicated emotional transactions of love and marriage established him as one of the most promising of the young American writers to emerge after World War II, died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: A New Group Linked to DeSantis Allies Pops Up in Iowa
description: The group, Fight Right, was registered in recent days as Gov. Ron DeSantis tries to boost his momentum heading into the Iowa caucuses.
content: A new political group with ties to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida began reserving airtime in Iowa on Monday, a surprising new player in the 2024 Republican primary that has emerged with less than two months until the Iowa caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Happy Thanksgiving, Hermit Billionaires!
description: There is always something to be grateful for.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I guess we should start with things we’re thankful for this year. Don’t suppose the imminent end of the political career of the dreadful Representative George Santos rises to the level of holiday cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Mette Lampcov
title: In Death Valley, a Rare Lake Comes Alive
description: Visitors normally flock to Death Valley National Park to feel the searing heat and take in the barren landscape. This fall, they’ve been drawn by a different natural feature: water.
content: Furnace Creek and Stovepipe Wells are among the roadside outposts inside Death Valley National Park, while Dante’s View draws tourists at sunset and Hell’s Gate greets visitors arriving from the east.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: ‘Congratulations, Birds’: Biden Pardons a Pair of Turkeys
description: The president celebrated his 81st birthday on the same day he spared two turkeys in the annual pre-Thanksgiving tradition.
content: For the 76th year in a row on Monday, an American president took part in the pre-Thanksgiving ritual of pardoning a turkey. And President Biden, who turned 81 on the same day he spared a pair of birds, wanted to get one thing straight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: ‘Lost Time for No Reason’: How Driverless Taxis Are Stressing Cities
description: In San Francisco and Austin, Texas, where passengers can hail self-driving vehicles, the cars have added to the workloads of city employees.
content: Around 2 a.m. on March 19, Adam Wood, a San Francisco firefighter on duty, received a 911 call and raced to the city’s Mission neighborhood to help a male who was having a medical emergency. After loading the patient into an ambulance, a black-and-white car pulled up and blocked the path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Kevin Roose and Cade Metz
title: Microsoft Hires Sam Altman Hours After OpenAI Rejects His Return
description: The announcement capped a tumultuous weekend for OpenAI, after Mr. Altman made a push to reclaim his job as C.E.O. of the artificial intelligence company.
content: The board of directors of OpenAI, the high-flying artificial intelligence start-up, said in a note to employees on Sunday night that its former chief, Sam Altman, would not be returning to his job, while naming his second interim replacement in two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Rosalynn Carter, White House Trendsetter
description: Her style contribution as first lady deserves a reassessment.
content: Rosalynn Carter, who died on Sunday at age 96, was rarely included on any list of best-dressed first ladies. She was not generally called “stylish” or “trendsetting.” She did not play the White House dress-up game, at least as designed by predecessors such as Dolley Madison and Jackie Kennedy. Most of the time, she seemed to actively reject it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitie Kelly
title: How to Apply Lipstick the Right Way
description: It does involve using a liner but not necessarily in the way you might think. Plus, tips for smoothing your skin and layering on color that won’t smudge.
content: Lipstick has been used, in various forms, for millenniums, but the struggle to make its color last has, seemingly, existed for just as long. Solutions have included the pots of red ocher that were often buried alongside mummies in ancient Egypt, to ensure a russet-lined smile well into the next life, and the potent mercury-laced vermilion mixture that was applied to rosebud effect in the Elizabethan era. Why go to all this trouble? Perfectly tinted lips “make you look finished and polished like nothing else can,” says Jenn Streicher, a makeup artist and founder of the New York beauty boutiques Scout and Duchess. Here, a guide to applying lipstick like a professional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: U.S. Defense Secretary Visits Ukraine in Show of Support
description: Lloyd J. Austin III’s trip was a gesture of solidarity when progress in the war against Russia has stalled and there are concerns about U.S. military aid.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III visited the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv on Monday, vowing support for its government at a time when progress in the war against Russia as well as U.S. military aid have both stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert and David Botti
title: Video Shows Yemen’s Houthi Militia Hijacking Ship in the Red Sea
description: The video, released by the Houthi militia, holds clues about when and where the ship was hijacked.
content: Yemen’s Houthi militia released a video on Monday showing its forces hijacking the ship Galaxy Leader, a day after announcing it had seized the vessel in the Red Sea as a demonstration of support for “the oppressed Palestinian people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Was This a Recurrence of Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma or Something Else?
description: “Go to the emergency room,” the doctor told him after hearing of his trip and fever, rash and whole-body weakness. “You need to be seen.”
content: The 57-year-old man looked up the long staircase that led to his rooms in the rectory, the residence he shared with three other priests. He gripped the handrail on either side of the stairs and forced his foot onto the first step. Slowly he pulled himself up the two flights of stairs to his rooms. His trip home to Boston from a conference in Asunción, Paraguay, had been rough. It was an overnight trip, but he hadn’t been able to sleep at all. Now all he wanted to do was take off his Roman collar and lie down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Who Is Emmett Shear, OpenAI’s Interim Chief Executive?
description: The former chief executive of Twitch has embraced “A.I. doomerism,” the fear that artificial intelligence could cause the end of humanity.
content: When Emmett Shear, the former chief executive of the livestreaming site Twitch, was named the interim chief executive of OpenAI on Sunday night, he might have seemed a curious choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. Offers Another Round of Free Covid Tests Through the Mail
description: Households may now order another four at-home tests, or eight if they have not placed an order since the program was revived in September.
content: Just in time for the holiday season, the Biden administration is offering Americans a fresh round of free at-home coronavirus tests through the Postal Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Turkey Doesn’t Have to Be the Only Game at the Table
description: NYT Games has made puzzles to play with your family before, during or after the Thanksgiving meal.
content: Christina Iverson and Tracy Bennett, who make puzzles for The New York Times, are offering a tidy potluck of seasonal games for NYT Cooking readers. Gather for some friendly competition, find out interesting trivia about the holiday or team up to see if you can outsmart others in your group. All you need are pencils, paper and volunteers to play the game host and keep score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 2024 Presidential Debate Dates and Locations Are Announced
description: The Commission on Presidential Debates will host three general election forums on Sept. 16, Oct. 1 and Oct. 9.
content: The Commission on Presidential Debates on Monday announced the dates and locations of three presidential debates to be held during the general election campaign next year, as well as one vice-presidential debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: A Big Year for India on the Global Stage Ends in Cricket Heartbreak
description: A dominant World Cup run closes with a loss to Australia in the final, a symbol of how far India has come and how far it still has to go.
content: The stage was amply set: an acrobatic air show by Indian military planes, performances by star Bollywood singers, a light display, lots of fireworks and — talked about as the highlight — an appearance by Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the vast stadium that bears his name.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Viktor Belenko, Who Defected to the West in a Jet Fighter, Dies at 76
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Nov. 20, 2023.
content: “If my regiment could see five minutes of what I saw today, there would be a revolution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
title: In Ukraine’s Slowed-Down War, Death Comes as Quickly as Ever
description: Ukraine is facing continual eastern assaults from Russian forces at a bloody cost for both sides, even as the lines on the map barely move.
content: The agony came in waves as the wounded Ukrainian soldier in the back of the ambulance slipped in and out of consciousness. The driver, hurtling past cratered fields on roads thick with mud, was racing to escape Russian artillery fire north of the city of Avdiivka, while hoping he was not spotted by drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: They Thought They’d Found the Perfect New York Loft. It Was Illegal.
description: Tenants of a Bronx building have been displaced since the city ordered them to vacate. They want the landlord to make repairs and for their loft apartments to be legalized.
content: The painter found out about the Bronx building for creative types on Craigslist. So did the fashion stylist and the air quality technician who calls himself “a wannabe artist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Judson Jones
title: Where Rain, Snow or Severe Storms Could Disrupt Thanksgiving Travel
description: A “wave of inclement weather” could cause delays for those traveling in the eastern two-thirds of the country this week.
content: It’s that time of the year when airports and highways are abundantly crowded as hosts of travelers make their yearly pilgrimage for turkey and stuffing. A pre-Thanksgiving storm may make travel more difficult for many as some regions register severe thunderstorms, gusty winds, heavy rain and even snow at some high elevations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: Freakishly Smart Falcons Run These Islands
description: The success of wild striated caracaras in a test suggests that the intellects of more bird species may be underestimated.
content: If you heard there were faraway islands full of hyperintelligent birds, you would be forgiven for assuming that they must be parrots or crows — the superstars of the brainy bird world. But travel to the Falkland Islands near the Argentine coast, and you’ll find not parrots or crows but freakishly smart falcons called striated caracaras.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Notes on Going Home
description: We are shaped by the landscapes we are born to as inescapably as any other earthly creature born to any other ecosystem.
content: I was irritated as I drove west from Nashville. The sun was in my eyes, and I was holding the steering wheel too tight because the car kept getting buffeted by the winds of trucks passing at an astonishingly illegal speed. At least I’m not heading east, I kept reminding myself, stuck behind one big rig trying to pass another on a steep mountain incline. On the flat lands of West Tennessee, even eighteen-wheelers can pass going 90 miles an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Mayor Who Used Racial Slurs Is Charged With 2 Unrelated Crimes
description: The mayor of Clark, N.J., who was taped using slurs, is accused of running his landscaping business from his township office and falsifying documents.
content: The mayor of a small town in suburban New Jersey who was recorded four years ago using racial slurs and saying he would never hire a female police officer was charged on Monday with two unrelated crimes linked to his private landscaping business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: How Microsoft’s Satya Nadella Kept the ‘Best Bromance in Tech’ Alive
description: Mr. Nadella moved fast to hire Sam Altman, who was pushed out of OpenAI on Friday, and asserted his company’s role in its partnership with the A.I. start-up.
content: Just two weeks ago, Microsoft’s Satya Nadella stood onstage next to OpenAI’s Sam Altman at the start-up’s conference in a former concert hall in San Francisco. Both wore black jeans, Mr. Altman in an army-green shirt and Mr. Nadella in navy casual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Keep Thanksgiving Going With This Leftover Turkey Soup
description: This fragrant recipe filled with chickpeas and farro is a cozy destination for the last of the holiday’s spread.
content: For soup enthusiasts across America, the post-Thanksgiving turkey broth can be as sacred as the holiday meal itself. In many households, even before the dishes and the leftovers are packed away, the turkey carcass and trimmings are nestled into a pot of water for their hourslong simmer. Leftover turkey soup is a cozy way to keep Thanksgiving’s bountiful spirit going for several more meals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Natalie Alcoba and Lucía Cholakian Herrera
title: Argentina Braces Itself for Its New ‘Anarcho-Capitalist’ President
description: Javier Milei has said that society is better without government. Now he is about to run Argentina’s.
content: Javier Milei was first introduced to the Argentine public as a combative television personality with an unruly hairdo and a tendency to insult his critics. So when he entered Argentina’s presidential race last year, he was viewed by many as a sideshow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How to Avoid Family Drama This Holiday Season
description: Sidestep old grudges and political disagreements, and give yourself the gift of peace.
content: For some families, tension around the holidays is quiet — all clenched teeth and subtle jabs. For others, it is big, loud and boozy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Samar Abu Elouf
title: 28 Premature Babies Evacuated From Gaza Arrive in Egypt. Others Never Had the Chance.
description: The newborns had become a symbol of the suffering at Al-Shifa Hospital, which was raided by Israeli forces last week.
content: Twenty-eight premature babies who had been in intensive care at the embattled Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza were transported across the border to Egypt for medical care on Monday, according to the United Nations and an Egyptian state television network, Al Qahera News. But five others who had been cared for at the hospital died before they could be evacuated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: The Winners and Losers of OpenAI’s Wild Weekend
description: It is hard to see the past few days as anything but a big loss for the A.I. company.
content: For a while this weekend, it looked as if Sam Altman might return as a conquering hero to OpenAI, the company whose board had fired him as chief executive on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Explaining the Upheaval at OpenAI
description: What comes next after Sam Altman’s messy ouster?
content: Hello! We’re back with another bonus edition of On Tech: A.I., a pop-up newsletter that teaches you about artificial intelligence, how it works and how to use it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia, K.K. Rebecca Lai, Josh Katz and Erin Schaff
title: ‘A Beautiful Place That Has a Dragon’: Where Hurricane Risk Meets Booming Growth
description: The combined threat of climate change and development in risky areas is making it a big challenge to keep coastal Carolina residents safe.
content: The combined threat of climate change and development in risky areas is making it a big challenge to keep coastal Carolina residents safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Popovich
title: How Electricity Is Changing Around the World
description: Renewable electricity is rising quickly, but the world’s power mix remains fossil fuel-heavy — for now.
content: Renewable electricity is rising quickly, but the world’s power mix remains fossil fuel-heavy — for now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Name These Famous Short Stories Based on Their Descriptions?
description: Try this five-question quiz to see how many brief works of literature have stuck around in your memory.
content: Try this five-question quiz to see how many brief works of literature have stuck around in your memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Moderated by Emily Bazelon
title: Was Peace Ever Possible?
description: Thirty years ago, a negotiated settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict seemed achievable. The story of how it fell apart reveals why the fight remains so intractable today.
content: Thirty years ago, a negotiated settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict seemed achievable. The story of how it fell apart reveals why the fight remains so intractable today.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Employee Letter to OpenAI’s Board
description: Hundreds of OpenAi employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled.
content: Hundreds of OpenAi employees signed a letter on Monday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Home with Nina Weinman
description: A Hallmark Channel screenwriter shares her secret for prevailing over all-cash offers. “What I do for a living gave me a little bit of an advantage.”
content: A Hallmark Channel screenwriter shares her secret for prevailing over all-cash offers. “What I do for a living gave me a little bit of an advantage.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters, Associated Press and Storyful
title: ‘It Was Terrible’: Taylor Swift Fans in Brazil Bear Heat and Dismay
description: Thousands of fans had already traveled to the stadium in Rio de Janeiro by the time the show on Saturday was called off because of safety concerns.
content: Thousands of fans had already traveled to the stadium in Rio de Janeiro by the time the show on Saturday was called off because of safety concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Collier and Santiago García Muñoz
title: Being Born in Gaza
description: Naya Qeshta was born in Rafah on November 11. Her mother, Samah, was one of tens of thousands of pregnant women in Gaza relying on a health care system that has been crippled by Israel’s ongoing siege.
content: Naya Qeshta was born in Rafah on November 11. Her mother, Samah, was one of tens of thousands of pregnant women in Gaza relying on a health care system that has been crippled by Israel’s ongoing siege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris, Jan Ransom, Rebecca Suner and Ruru Kuo
title: Inside Our Reporting
description: Amid a drumbeat of incidents involving homeless, mentally ill people, officials in New York said they were doing their best. The reality is different, a New York Times investigation has found.
content: Amid a drumbeat of incidents involving homeless, mentally ill people, officials in New York said they were doing their best. The reality is different, a New York Times investigation has found.
source.name: The New York Times
